problem: A 56.5-kg hiker starts at an elevation of 1270 m and climbs to the top of a 2660-m peak. (a) What is the hiker's change in potential energy? (b) What is the minimum work required of the hiker? (c) Can the actual work done be greater than this? Explain.

steps.explanation: We will use the change in gravitational potential energy formula.
Define the variables with values given in the problem.
Substitute the numerical values into the formula.
Calculate the change in potential energy.
For part (b), the minimum work required equals the increase in potential energy when no energy is lost to nonconservative forces.

For part (c), yes, the actual work done can be greater than this minimum. Real hikes involve inefficiencies such as non-vertical paths, friction, air resistance, and metabolic inefficiencies in the body, so the actual work exceeds the ideal minimum.
steps.notations: W₍actual₎ > W₍min₎ due to nonconservative forces

solution:
ΔU = m g Δy
Given: m = 56.5 kg, yᵢ = 1270 m, y₍f₎ = 2660 m, g = 9.80 m/s²
Δy = y₍f₎ - yᵢ = 2660 m - 1270 m = 1390 m
ΔU = (56.5 kg)(9.80 m/s²)(1390 m)
ΔU = 7.69 × 10⁵ J ≈ 7.7 × 10⁵ J
W₍min₎ = ΔU = 7.7 × 10⁵ J
Actual work can exceed this minimum due to nonconservative forces (friction, non-vertical path, metabolic inefficiency)
